content:
<icemelon> we reviewed the kzg-ceremony crptco code. in general it looks great. we made two comments/updates that could improve its security and performance:
- Zeroize entropy after a contribution is made (https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/pull/60)
- deferred pairing-checks and used pairing products when possible (https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/pull/61)

<CarlBeek> > <CarlBeek>  I'd appreciate any feedback y'all have on this when anyone has a moment. I'd like to merge it soon so we can get hacking. Points that are worth thinking about:

1) are the correct things being signed
2) does everyone have support for the `BLS_SIG_BLS12381G1_XMD:SHA-256_SSWU_RO_POP_` chiphersuite in their favourite BLS lib. (This is not the same one as ethereum is using as Pubkeys are in G2)
3) @Recmo am I doing eip712 correctly
4) Are there any safety issues anyone sees with what is being signed? (re @CarlBeek: The long-awaited double signing proposal is here: https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-specs/pull/33

It looks like far more LOC changes than it really is due to lots of string manipulation for EIP712.)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<Recmo> > deffered pairing checks.
I considered this, and even had an implementation, but removed it in the end because it adds quite a bit of complexity (now need to store, mutate and handle an accumulator). The performance gains are reducing 4×3 paring checks to one. A paring check takes 3ms (arkworks) 1ms (blst). Compared to the ~1000 ms of the rest of the validation this is only a ~1% perf improvement.
